conclusion: To determine if the particle undergoes linear motion with gradually decreasing acceleration from 1 to 2 seconds, we need to analyze the velocity-time (v-t) graph provided.
The x-axis represents time (t) in seconds. The y-axis represents velocity (v) in meters per second (m/s). The graph shows how the velocity of the particle changes over time.
Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity with respect to time, which can be determined by the slope of the v-t graph.
A straight line on a v-t graph indicates constant acceleration.
A curve on a v-t graph indicates changing acceleration.
From 1 to 2 seconds, the graph shows a curve that is concave down, meaning the slope of the tangent to the curve is decreasing.
This indicates that the acceleration is decreasing over this interval.
Since the velocity is changing and the acceleration is decreasing, the motion is not uniformly accelerated.
The particle is undergoing linear motion, but the acceleration is not constant; it is gradually decreasing.
Yes, it is correct to say that the particle undergoes linear motion with gradually decreasing acceleration from 1 to 2 seconds.
